dialogues.speaker: EMPTY ROOM WITH SINGLE CHAIR
dialogues.text: We hear a DOOR OPEN and CLOSE, followed by APPROACHING FOOTSTEPS. DANNY OCEAN, dressed in prison fatigues, ENTERS FRAME and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please state your name for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Mr. Ocean, the purpose of this meeting is to determine whether, if released, you are likely to break the law again. While this was your first conviction, you have been implicated, though never charged, in over a dozen other confidence schemes and frauds. What can you tell us about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you say, ma'am, I was never charged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three PAROLE BOARD MEMBERS sit opposite Danny, behind a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ocean, what we're trying to find out is: was there a reason you chose to commit this crime, or was there a reason why you simply got caught this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife left me. I was upset.    I got into a self-destructive pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If released, is it likely you would fall back into a similar pattern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She already left me once. I don't think she'll do it again just for kicks. Glances dart between the Board Members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ocean, what do you think you would do if released? Danny considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. How much do you guys make a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ocean, Daniel. Danny steps forth, and GUARD #1 doles out his possessions and a form certifying their return to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign. (adding a piece of mail to the pile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This came today for you. Rest'll be forwarded to your parole officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading its return address over Danny's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those your lawyers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's. He opens the letter, and as his eyes gaze over the papers within, he smirks just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a free man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny pulls on civilian clothes and there's not a bare thread among them. He tugs his cuffs and smiles: The old skin feels good. One last item to don: a silver wedding band. Danny considers it. Will he put it on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads: "NEW JERSEY STATE MINIMUM-SECURITY CORRECTIONAL FACILITY." Someone has graffitied below it: "If you were in prison, you'd be home now." The great metal door opens, and Danny stands within its frame, ready for release. (If it matters -- and if you notice -- he's wearing his wedding ring.) He hovers   there for a moment, on the precipice of freedom.    The WIND WHISTLES a little on the other side the gate,   and the view ahead is not pleasant (New Jersey):    Life is hard out there. But Danny musters his courage, then takes his first step into free America...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any empty wintery boardwalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And his wingtip lands squarely on plush red carpeting. As we PULL UP TO Danny's face and SPIN AROUND him, we hear, then see the BUZZ of a CASINO floor: the HUM of CONVERSATION, the DING-DING-DING and THUNK-THUNK-THUNK from the SLOTS, the brisk WHIR of SHUFFLED CARDS. And to Danny, it's a hearth and fire and a comfy chair and a snifter of brandy. He's home.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY'S WALLET
dialogues.text: As he pulls out several crisp one hundreds, sets them on green felt, then sees them replaced by a neat pile of chips.

dialogues.speaker: AT BLACKJACK TABLE
dialogues.text: Danny cranes his neck about the casino, looking for someone -- a friend, somebody who should be here -- but without success. He turns his attention back to his cards, and the cards of the dealer. Nine-ten. Stay. Dealer -- seventeen. Danny wins. King-four. Dealer shows a six. Stick. Dealer busts. Queen-ace. Twenty-one. Danny wins again. A second dealer relieves the first, and Danny recognizes him with a smile -- this wasn't the friend he was scouting for, but two hours out of the joint any familiar face is welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Frank. The new dealer (FRANK CATTON) glances up at Danny, and his eyes go wide, like a priest who's discovered he's dealing communion wafers to the pontiff himself. He quickly hides his astonishment. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, sir. You must have me confused with someone else. My name is Ramon. See? He taps the name embroidered on his vest, although he is the most African-looking Ramon you've ever seen. A pit boss circles close by and glares at them both. DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mistake... (collecting his chips, doubled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table's cold anyway. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might try the lounge at the Grand, sir. It gets busy around one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny checks his watch -- 12:58 -- then the lounge around him: prison had more nightlife. He nurses a bourbon, folds back the New York Times and scans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His eyes move down the page and stop at a header -- "Vegas' Paradiso to be Razed; Former Owner Denounces Plans" -- accompanied by two photographs... The first: Tan, well-coiffed developer and new owner of the Paradiso, Terry Benedict, with a beautiful (if barely visible) woman on his arm. The second: scowling former owner, Reuben Tishkoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catching up on current events? Danny lowers the paper; Frank is sitting across from him, changed out of his dealer's threads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet you. Frank Catton wouldn't get by the gaming board. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Danny's drink and whereabouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And already turning over a new leaf. Frank signals a passing waitress; she ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (directly, this is why he's here)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last I heard he was in L.A. Teaching movie stars how to play cards. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? You don't have something planned already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kidding? I just became a citizen again. Frank stares at Danny a moment, finally catches his eye, and Danny can't help but grin: of course he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank turns his eyes to heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING WITH Danny and Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tough now, our line of work. Everybody so serious. Too many guns, too many computers. Whadda you gonna do? Steal from ordinary people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's left? Banks? Hah. Banks got no money. It's all electronic. Only place that still takes cash is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casinos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon.   Interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank smiles.    Danny has his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny pulls a business card from his jacket, picks up the phone again, and dials the card's number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Officer Brooks? My name is Danny Ocean. I'm just out, I'm supposed to check in with you within twenty-four hours. (listens) No, sir, I haven't gotten into any trouble. No drinking, no sir. (listens, finishes his bourbon) No, sir, I wouldn't even think of leaving the state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF the sound of a JET fly-over we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULLING OFF the Capitol Building, we PICK UP Rusty (tall, angular, ebony) leaning against his Ford Falcon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   Hey, Rusty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty turns to the voice and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING WITH him and Topher Grace, the actor, as they push down a back alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I don't know if you're, uh, you know, incorporated or anything, like Rusty Ryan. And, I don't know, incorporated, but you should think about it, really, 'cause I was talking to my manager yesterday --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not Bernie, I mean not, not that Bernie, my business manager, he's also Bernie, he was telling me that since this, what we do, could be considered research for, you know, a future gig, that I should be able to write it off as a business expense. So he suggested that it'd be better if I wrote you a check, and thereby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty looks at him:     are you stoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, or we could keep it cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time, they should have entered --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where they must weave through hordes of young Hollywood nightclubbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   Who's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh is here. Seth is here. David couldn't make it. He's got two weeks of reshoots on Lusitania because somebody just figured out forty percent of the budget is coming from Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they let him out to do that H.B.O. thing in Vancouver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't work the dates. Oh, and he brought his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the one from --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I quit watching when Kate left Don after his accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass on, and into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small but stylish.     Rusty enters, Topher in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, guys. Let's play some cards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glance at the table reveals: the three waiting players are all young TV stars (Josh Jackson, Seth Green, Barry Watson) here for a group poker lesson with Rusty. (One star, indeed, has brought his girlfriend, Katie, also a known actress, to observe.) A glance back at Rusty reveals:     he's in for a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and let's play some cards.

dialogues.speaker: AT TABLE
dialogues.text: The group lesson has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred bucks to me... (mulling it over) Ah, what the hell. Pocket change. Call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty leans into Topher's ear, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you bet a certain way is your business. But you have to make them think you're betting for a reason. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: To another player:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth. You know what you have. Looking at them doesn't change them. Leave 'em where they are and make your bet.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: To another player:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're showing. Yeah, I know she's your girlfriend, Barry, but you can't... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: To another:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh.   Deal to your left.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS enters from the club, and DANCE MUSIC with her. As she distributes a fresh round:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One McCallum neat. And four bottled waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty takes in the sight -- bottled fucking water on a poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) Two pair -- nines and twos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty checks his hand:     a full-house full of face card

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding) You got me. (as Seth rakes in his winnings) Let's take a little break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, Rusty orders a double.     He needs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting over music) How's the game going?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been the longest hour of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the same volume) I'm running away with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bartender, not able to hear him, smiles and flashes a thumbs-up before moving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the bar two go-go dancers writhe behind red-light- district windows, and Rusty catches his own fatigued expression in their reflection. Then, out the corner of his eye, he catches sight of a man passing through the pulsating crowd. Someone familiar to him. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rusty, we got another player, if that's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: A15 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Topher indicates the new arrival: Danny.       Rusty look as if there's a bad smell in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bouncer mentioned there was a game in progress. I hope I'm not intruding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No intrusion at all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was his name, the bouncer's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A card player with amnesia.    This should be fun.

dialogues.speaker: AT TABLE
dialogues.text: Rusty deals the next hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living, Mr. Ocean? If you don't mind my asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I mind? Two cards, please... (long beat) I just got out of prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? (a glance among the other players) Really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half to divert attention) Barry, you're showing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you, uh, go to prison for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, like jewels? Diamonds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incan matrimonial headmasks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks are exchanged.      Everyone digests that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a museum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There a lot of money in those? Incan matrimonial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headmasks.   Some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him fool you, Seth. There's boatloads. If you can move the things... (finishing his deal) One card to me. (to Danny, pointedly) ... but you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fence seemed confident enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're dealing with cash, you don't need a fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people just lack vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably everybody in cell block E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: A15 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now the other players realize. These guys have a relationship. In fact, a criminal one. And, judging from their steely glares across the table, not a happy one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's all behind us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny smiles, icily -- of course, it's not -- then pulls out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I raise you five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hush in the room. Danny has thrown down the gauntlet. He and Rusty hold each other's stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys: Day One: what's the first rule of poker?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY TOPHER
dialogues.text: Um, never bet on, uh, on           'Leave emotion at the a --                               door.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. My friend here just raised me out of pique. (beat) Today's lesson. How to draw out a bluff. This early in the game, that much money, I'm thinking he's holding nothing better than a pair of face cards. (beat) Seth, raise him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Uh, your five hundred and... another two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty nods, and Seth pushes in his chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tophe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven to me.   Plus three.   What the hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. But be careful you don't push him too high too fast. Want to keep him on the leash. I call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Josh's turn.       He hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that to me? A thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Josh's further hesitation) What? Your girlfriend holding your purse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it. Josh is in. The bet's to Danny. He checks his hand, and Seth starts to whisper to Topher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contrary to what Mr. Ryan may say, Seth, I always check my cards before I make a bet. But be cafeful. I could tell from your face you're holding three of a kind or better. (digging his wallet out) Five hundred to call. And two grand more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny stares Rusty down.      The others look a little pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, you're free to do what you like. It's a lot of money. But I'm staying in. He's trying to buy his way out of his bluff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody looks too eager to call, but nobody wants to leave a grand on the table, either. Finally, Seth ponies up, and the others -- not be outdone -- do, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sets down his hand. Four nines. It's a winner. The others, jaws dropped, throw in their cards. For the first time tonight, Rusty blanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Sorry, guys. I -- I was sure he was bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rusty plummets in the estimation of all the guys around him, Danny rakes in his pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the game, fellas. (then) Hey, I hate to ask this, but could you sign something for me? It's for the guys in the joint. They just love all your shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A queue of clubgoers erupt in a frenzy as Topher and company exit, and they begin signing autographs. Danny and Rusty exit, too, but of course nobody gives a shit about them.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty ride silently, staring out opposite windows at Sunset Boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was, that was just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was the clink? You get the cookies I sent you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think I came to see you first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny pulls out a wad of bills from his jacket, peels off half, and hands it to Rusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten grand.   Half of it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 5/31/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You barge into my new workplace, ruin my professional reputation, least you could do is tell me you've got something better for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something better for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're sitting in a booth over coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Tess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny stares at him:       next subject, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tricky. No one's ever done it before. Needs planning, a large crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not loaded ones. It has to be very precise. There's a lot of security. But the take...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the target?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight figures each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's.    The.    Target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep breath, then) When's the last time you were in Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You wanna knock over a casino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny puts down his coffee. And shakes his head. And lifts three fingers: three casinos. Rusty must put down his coffee, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after hours downtown.    Dark, empty, dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights out on the 40th. Engraved brass announces:     J.A KUEHN & ASSOCIATES, ARCHITECTS. Two flashlight beams strafe wood-paneled, elegant offices: Danny and Rusty on late-night reconnaissance. As Danny prowls a cabinet full of blueprints, Rusty passes the time switching papers from a desk's in box to its out box. At last, Danny finds the right set of blueprints and drapes it across the desk; we, however, never see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vault at the Bellagio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Rusty scans the document, then another underneath it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm reading these right -- and I think that I am -- this is probably the least accessible vault ever designed. (beat) Oops. Actually, you know what, I'm wrong. It's definitely the least accessible vault ever designed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty's brow furrows just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said three casinos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips to next blueprint) These feed into the cages at both the Mirage and the M.G.M. Grand. (tapping vault) But every dime ends up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bellagio, Mirage, and... These are Terry Benedict's places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they are.     Think he'll mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: AT 40TH FLOOR ELEVATOR BAY
dialogues.text: No ding. The elevator just arrives. Its doors part to reveal a SECURITY GUARD within, here to make his tour; a large fellow, he has to duck to exit.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH DANNY AND RUSTY
dialogues.text: As Danny rolls up the set of blueprints, Rusty considers the plan (which, in our absence, Danny has pitched him).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd need at least a dozen guys, doing a combination of cons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what, you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, off the top of my head, I'd say you're looking at a Boesky, a Jim Brown, a Miss Daisy, two Jethros, and a Leon Spinks. Oh, and the biggest Ella Fitzgerald ever. (beat) Where do you think you're gonna get the money to back this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as we're hitting these three casinos, we'll get our bankroll. Terry Benedict has a list of enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But does he have enemies with loose cash and nothing to lose... (smiles, realizing) Aha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, too) Aha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: as he approaches Danny's and Rusty's voices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, here's what I think: You should take this plan, kick it around for a week or two. Sleep on it. Turn it over in your head. Then: never bring it up to me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.    So what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying: this is like trying to build a house of cards on the deck of a speeding boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I thought it was much harder than that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Security Guard's flashlight beam hits them square in the eyes. Danny and Rusty put their hands up to block the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Oscar, lower it a little, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. (lowers beam) You two done up here?    Find what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. You mind if we borrow a couple drawings for the night? Make some copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny withdraws his money clip, peels off a couple hundreds, and buries them in the Security Guard's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Preciate it.

dialogues.speaker: AT 40TH FLOOR ELEVATOR BAY
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty wait for an elevator. When its doors open, Rusty stops Danny from boarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a reason. And don't say money. (beat) Why do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty stares at him:    enough bullshitting around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because yesterday I walked out of the joint wearing my entire wardrobe and you're colddecking TeenBeat coverboys. (beat) Because the house always wins. You play long enough, never changing stakes, the house takes you. Unless, when that special hand comes around, you bet big. And then you take the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.   Rusty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're been practicing that speech, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little. Did I rush it?   It felt like I rushed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step aboard the elevator.     As the door closes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what Reuben will say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of your goddamn minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REUBEN TISHKOFF, the grimace of a man in mid-movement, forever cemented on his face, scrutinizes his two lunch guests (Danny and Rusty) at his poolside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me? You are, both of you, nuts. I know more about casino security than any man alive. I invented it, and it cannot be beaten. They got cameras, they got watchers, they got locks, they got timers, they got vaults. They got enough armed personnel to occupy Paris. Okay, bad example...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never been tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's been tried. A few guys even came close. You know the three most successful robberies in Vegas history?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: An Adlai Stevenson-lookalike approaches a lockbox carrier from behind and snatches the box.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes almost three steps before five security men leap at him and -- FREEZE FRAME on his wide-eyed expression of horror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number three. The bronze medal. Pencilneck grabs a lockbox at the Sands. He got two steps closer to the door than any living soul before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME ACTION: Adlai Stevenson gets a taste of what NFL quarterbacks experience every Sunday... five fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hippie races toward the electronic sliding doors, clutching a tray full of chips, and as the doors begin to part for him -- FREEZE FRAME: A billy club appears out of nowhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second most successful robbery. The Flamingo '71. This guy actually smelled fresh oxygen before they got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME ACTION: The billy club comes down -- whap! -- across the hippie's skull and it's Chicago '68 all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course, he was breathing out of a hose the next three weeks, goddamn hippie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the closest any man has gotten to robbing a Las Vegas casino...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Tourists and valets scatter as a Euro-thief (pastel T-shirt beneath a white linen suit) bursts from the casino and takes five steps before -- FREEZE FRAME: GLASS EXPLODES from three different doors behind him and he arches his back in agony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of Caesar's in '87.   He came, he grabbed, he got conquered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME ACTION: BULLETS rip the man to shreds and he collapses on Caesar's steps a bloody pulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what am I saying? You guys are pros, the best. I'm sure you can make it out of the casino. Of course, lest we forget, once you're out the front door, you're still in the middle of the fucking desert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Danny and Rusty look chastened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. (to Danny) He's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben, you're right. Our eyes are bigger than our stomachs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly it. Pure ego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah blah blah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for setting us straight. Sorry we bothered you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both rise to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we all go way back. I owe you from that thing with the guy in the place, and I'll never forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was our pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never been to Belize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give Dominic your addresses, I got some remaindered furniture I wanna send you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty begin to circle the pool to leave. Tishkoff, of course, won't let them go that easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just out of curiosity, which casinos did you geniuses pick to rob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny stops, almost as if he's been waiting for this question, which of course he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bellagio, Mirage, and the M.G.M. Grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nostrils flared, smelling a rat) Those are Terry Benedict's casinos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you know, he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tishkoff waves them back, sipping on his umbrellaed cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys... Whadda you got against Terry Benedict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have against him? That's the real question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He torpedoed my casino, muscled me out, now he's gonna blow it up next month to make way for another fuckin' eyesore. Don't think I don't see what you're doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing, Reuben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna steal from Terry Benedict, you better goddamn know. This sorta thing used to be civilized. You'd hit a guy, he'd whack you. Done. But Benedict... (bristles) At the end of this he better not know you're involved, not know your names, or think you're dead. Because he'll kill you, and then he'll go to work on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we've got to be very careful. We have to be precise. We have to be well-funded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you gotta be nuts, too. And you're gonna need a crew as nuts as you are. (pregnant silence) Who do you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty both smile; they've hooked their fish. And so it begins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   Who's in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank C. is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Catton coughs mightily into a handkerchief.   Acros a desk, his boss fills out paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank C. has developed a bad case of bronchitis and is putting in for a transfer to warmer climates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank carries his bag toward the taxi bay. He stops to light a cigarette, inhales with deep satisfaction before a banner: "WELCOME TO LAS VEGAS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about drivers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01                               22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a souped-up tractor-wheeled monster truck, its ENGINE ROARING before a starting line, itching to cross it. Now take a step back... That souped-up monster truck stands a foot-and-a-half off the ground and sprouts an antenna from its back bumper. It's a remote-controlled toy. The ROARING ENGINE comes from the vehicle next to it: an actual monster truck. Both vehicles peer down the track at a finish line a hundred yards away. This is a race. The drivers stare each other down: TURK (behind the wheel of the truck) and VIRGIL (track-side, remote control in hand) MALLOY. They're nice boys. Really. Peckerwoods, sure, but nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to the Malloys yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mormon twins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both in Salt Lake City, six months off the job. I got the sense they're having trouble filling the hours. Lights flash red-to-yellow-to-green and while the TRUCK COATS RUBBER on the track, Virgil's toy zips to a lead. It's looking to be an embarrassment for Turk until he jerks his wheel a little and -- ka-thunk -- flattens his brother's vehicle. Virgil pouts as he plucks up the wreckage of his entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electronics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston Dell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a black and white monitor: Two mobsters, on a meet in a public park, peer over their shoulders, making certain no one is watching them. Little do they know... ... LIVINGSTON DELL, audio-visual junkie, and victim of a continual flop sweat, crouches before their image, masterfully controlling his surveillance camera with a joystick in his left hand. He is flanked by FBI MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston's been doing freelance surveillance work of late for the F.B.I. Mob Squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are his nerves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (beat) Not so bad you'd notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a FBI Man reaches to adjust a monitor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D-don't, don't-don't... touch... it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see me pulling the gun out of your holster and firing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Radio Shack: relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston walks down the boardwalk. A rollerblader with dog on a leash approaches and Livingston gets caught between the two. As he struggles to untangle himself from the leash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a view of Livingston on the boardwalk...       Danny Rusty wait for him over espressos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (next item on his list) Munitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil Turentine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01                            23A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit?   On the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You send flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dated his wife a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (onto next candidate) Basher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) We may be too late.

dialogues.speaker: BASHER TARR
dialogues.text: the explosives expert. A pair of goggles over his eyes reflects a match being struck, then touched to a fuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! Wood shards and SPLINTERS of GLASS fly all around; Basher merely ducks his head and whistles. As the dust settles, three men move quickly past Basher and into (what the settling fog now reveals to be) a dynamited bank vault. ALARMS begin to sound: this is bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the rest of his gang, his temper flaring) You know, you guys had one job to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men exit through the front doors, their hands over their heads, Basher trailing them. Policemen and SWAT members encircle the group, weapons trained on them, chock full of instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basher sits in the rear, handcuffed behind his back, feet on the pavement. An explosives COP kneels in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all you used during the event? Nothing else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you accusing me of booby- trapping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how 'bout it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booby traps aren't Mr. Tarr's style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cop turns; standing behind him, stone-faced, is Rusty, in a dark suit and shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that right, Basher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing badge, briefly) Peck, A.T.F. Let me venture a guess. A simple G4 mainliner, double-coil, backwound, quick fuse with a drag under 20 feet. (off Cop's reaction) That's our man. Tell me something else. Have you checked him for booby traps on his person? I mean really checked, not just for weapons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cop looks bewildered. Rusty steps forward, yanks Basher onto his feet, spins him around. He moves his hands up and down Basher's legs, around his waist, under his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you go find Griggs and tell him I need to see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) Just go find him, will you? (as Cop stalks off; under his breath) How fast can you put something together with what I passed you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.   Thirty seconds all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as we hear something SNAP from behind his back) Now.

dialogues.speaker: RUSTY AND BASHER
dialogues.text: They're hurrying; ahead of them is a wall of squad cars, a police cordon, and a crowd of onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten seconds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite.   Is Danny here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good working with professionals again. (beat) Okay: go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they both start running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone down! Get down!      There's a bomb in the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And behind them the SQUAD CAR ERUPTS with a BANG! A collective SCREAM rises from the crowd, everyone ducks, cops hit the ground and cover their heads. Rusty and Basher move briskly past them, dodging their splayed legs like tires on an obstacle course. By the time the Explosives Cop thinks to look around for Basher, they've both disappeared. OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01                              27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese National Circus, currently on tour in the Western United States. Trapeze artists, gymnastic teams, and trampoline daredevils fly, somersault, spin, and swing through the air. A full house applauds every feat. Danny and Rusty sit in the bleachers, surrounded by parents and kids munching on spindles of cotton candy. Tough guys in toyland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Chinese, then English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen: the amazing Yen. A funambulist (YEN) begins his high-wire act...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he can walk on a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he can juggle. We need a grease man, not an acrobat. Who else is on the list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway across the wire, the funambulist sits. And very slowly, but without hesitation, he contorts himself into a ball, never losing his balance. Even Danny is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your grease man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty exit the circus tent, head for their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need Saul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't come. He swore off the game a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He get religion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulcers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty stops, stares at Danny, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAUL BLOOM, 50s, befuddled, wearing a corduroy jacket patched at the elbows and a duffer's hat, counts out money through the window, lists his bets. He checks his tickets, plunges them into his pants pocket, and moves off...

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH TRACK LOBBY
dialogues.text: Rusty appears in the f.g. behind a pillar, as dapper as Saul is down-at-heel, watching him go. When Saul disappears into the tunnel, he moves.

dialogues.speaker: IN INFIELD
dialogues.text: Saul sits on one of the long, general admission steps under the box seats. He produces an orange from his pocket, starts to peel it. A pair of well-shined shoes appears behind him. Saul senses their presence, but doesn't turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you in the paddock before the second race, outside the men's room, when I placed my bet. I saw you before you even got up this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya been, Saul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the orange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My doctor says I need vitamins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't you take vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Saul cranes his neck and shoots a look up at Rusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come here to give me a physical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a box seat. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter serves coffee to Rusty and Saul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you drank bloody Mary's at the track, Saul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man shouldn't drink on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: race) Who we rooting for here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the BELL; the electronic rabbit is released and the dogs break out of the gate. From this point on Saul's eyes never leave the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna ask me? Or should I just say no and get it over with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saul, you're the best there is. You're in Cooperstown. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. I got a duplex now, I got wall-to-wall and a goldfish, I'm seeing a nice lady, she works the unmentionables counter at Macy's. I've changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys like us don't change, Saul. We stay sharp or we get sloppy, but we don't change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit connin' me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They watch the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your hound way in the back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks late. Everyone knows this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the track: The dogs are now coming around the back stretch, and the crowd on the bleachers rises, cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna treat me like a grownup at least? Tell me what the scam is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the noise: Rusty leans in and whispers in Saul's ear. Saul's eyes widen, then glaze over as all around him people are standing and shouting. Rusty places an envelope in Saul's lap, then gets up and walks out as, on the track, the #4 dog crosses the finish line... last by several lengths. Saul considers his options. In one hand: a fan of losing tickets. In the other (courtesy of Rusty): a ticket to Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Saul makes ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty look weary from all this recruitment.   A nearby TV with the sound off plays a promo for an upcoming Tyson fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten should do it, don't you think? (as Rusty shrugs) You think we need one more? (as Rusty shrugs) You think we need one more. (as Rusty shrugs) Okay. We'll get one more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Native Chicagoans demonstrate their indigenous sixth sense -- L-car balance -- as the TRAIN bends and SHAKES at a corner.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One passenger in particular keeps his footing, a young man in a frayed jacket: LINUS. Two overgroomed STOCKBROKERS stand with their backs to the young man, yammering about high interest yields, and consequently they don't notice (and neither do we, not at first) that Linus is slowly picking one of their pockets. The thievery is glacier-paced: Linus, his face always forward and inscrutable, gingerly raises one tail of his target's Brooks Brothers jacket and then, with incomparable dexterity, unbuttons his wallet pocket with a flick of his thumb and forefinger. From halfway down the train car, nothing appears amiss, and no passenger looks the wiser. Or so it seems... A copy of the Chicago Sun-Times, opened and upheld, lowers just enough to allow its reader a peek at Linus. It is Danny, smirk on his lips: He (and he alone) is aware of the ongoing heist. Back to Linus, his spoils (a Gucci wallet) now in sight, but he waits for just the right moment, and then, when the train hits another curve... ... he stumbles forward, his left hand finding support on the Stockbroker's shoulder as his right relieves the man of his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry 'bout that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stockbroker resumes his yacketing, oblivious, as Linus tucks his prize into his own jacket pocket, face betraying nothing. Only Danny appreciates the artistry performed here today. He folds the Sun-Times under his arm as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The SUBWAY SQUEALS to a stop. Linus jumps out, leaving his prey aboard, and a few moments later, Danny steps off, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hurly-burly of rush hour in Union Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Commuters zig and zag, this way and that, all on furious schedules, and Linus slips blithely through them, in no hurry, a man who's pulled this job a thousand times before. He dodges and sidesteps crazed commuters, and except for a brief brush with one well-dressed man (the Sun-Times tucked under his arm), he escapes the station without incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linus exits, casually reaching into his jacket to count his winnings. And his face falls. All he finds where the stolen wallet once resided is a calling card. On one side, in engraved printing: "DANIEL OCEAN." On the flip side, in handwriting: "Nice pull. Murphy's Bar, Rush & Division."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a tabletop: the Gucci wallet beside a half-drunk Guinness. Linus enters the front door, cases the joint, spots the wallet on the table, and Danny behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Linus.   Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of Bobby Caldwell's.   Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linus balks, prideful, but sense finds a way, and he sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby told me about you. Said you were the best set of hands he ever saw. Didn't expect to find you working wallets on the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't work, that was practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny reaches into his jacket and sets a plane ticket on the table. He keeps his hand over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're either in or out, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plane ticket. A job offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty trusting pretty fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby has every faith in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fathers are like that. (off Danny's reaction) He didn't tell you? (as Danny shakes his head) He doesn't like me trading on his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do this job, he'll be trading on yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I say no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get someone else who won't be quite as good. You can go back to feeling up stockbrokers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linus considers. He looks down at the ticket, then at the wallet. It's one or the other. A waitress passes, and Danny signals her for his bill. When his attention returns to Linus, the wallet remains... but the ticket beneath his hand is gone. Linus is reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best lift I've seen you make yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Las Vegas, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: America's playground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And our MAIN THEME KICKS IN as we...

dialogues.speaker: LAS VEGAS
dialogues.text: The city looms out of the desert like an infernal machine, lights flashing, skyline pulsing, a neon fortress. One thing in particular catches our eye: an enormous billboard with an ad for the upcoming boxing match between Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis. Below it, a promoter hands out fliers for strip joints and call girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Catton is already here, mixing a drink, when -- DING DONG -- the DOORBELL CHIMES. Tishkoff shuffles toward the front (he's given the help the night off) and opens his door to find...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick or treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Livingston, Basher, Yen, the Malloys, Saul and Linus crowding his doormat. A taxi-van pulls away behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you guys get a group rate or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along one wall, a buffet table has been set up, and while Virgil and Turk pile shrimp onto plates, Saul pockets an orange for later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it out to Utah much, Saul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (last man you'd see in the Tabernacle) Not as much as I'd like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should.   You'd like it.   You'd like Provo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scarfing a jumbo shrimp) Anybody see the salsa goes with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the wet bar, Basher mixes a drink for Livingston; on a couch, Yen balances coffee-table ornaments into a skyscraper, to Frank's astonishment. In a corner, off on his own, Linus watches the company, his eyes narrowing, wary. Until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen:    welcome to Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny stands at the top of the stairs leading into the room, flanked by Rusty and Tishkoff. He starts down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody eaten? Good. Everybody sober? Close enough. Most of you know each other already. You probably haven't met Linus Caldwell before, he's Bobby's kid outta Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linus trades nods around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Before we start, nobody's on the line here yet. What I'm about to propose to you happens to be both highly lucrative and highly dangerous. If that doesn't sound like your particular brand of vodka, help yourself to as much food as you like and safe journey. No hard feelings. (pauses, soberly) Otherwise, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks out of the living room, into another. Rusty is close behind; he turns briefly, casts an eye over the assembled and keeps going. The guys look each other over, sizing things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he follows, along with Frank and Livingston. Then Virgil, Turk and Yen. Then Saul. That leaves Linus, watching the line of men disappear. He turns to find Tishkoff by his side, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Bobby Caldwell's kid, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice there. You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful. Get in the goddamn room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tournament-level pool table holds center stage here. Atop its green felt sits a raised, elaborate miniature of Terry Benedict's Las Vegas: three casinos and hotels with the Strip running between them. As the eleven surround the table and the model...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen: the 14000 block of Las Vegas Boulevard. Otherwise known as the Bellagio, the Mirage, the M.G.M. Grand. Together, they're the three most profitable casinos in Las Vegas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny removes the Strip from the model. Revealed beneath is a complex substructure, featuring three tunnels, each leading from a casino to a single freight-sized elevator shaft which descends into an enormous vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen: the Bellagio vault. Located below the Strip, beneath two hundred feet of solid earth. It safeguards every dime that comes through each of the three casinos above it. (beat) And we're going to rob it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone takes a breath, awed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smash-and-grab job, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny picks up a remote control and flips on a panel of Tvs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courtesy of Frank Catton, new blackjack dealer at the Bellagio, security tapes from the three casinos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the monitors: three montages of black-and-white security tapes, starting within the three casinos' cages, moving into the tunnels, then (as the TVs unite in their images) pushing into the elevator and eventually the vault. As the group's glances shoot back and forth from the TV to the corresponding section of the model, i.e. from a POV of the tunnel to the miniature tunnel itself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.    Bad news first. This place houses   a security system which rivals   most nuclear missile silos. First:    we have to get within the casino   cages --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) -- here, here, and here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which anyone knows takes more than a smile. Next: through these doors, each of which requires a different six-digit code changed every twelve hours. Past those lies the elevator, and this is where it gets tricky: the elevator won't move without authorized fingerprint identifications --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which we can't fake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and vocal confirmations from both the security center within the Bellagio and the vault below - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which we won't get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furthermore, the elevator shaft is rigged with motion detectors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- meaning if we manually override the lift, the shaft's exit will lock down automatically and we'll be trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once we've gotten down the shaft, though, then it's a walk in the park: just three more guards with Uzis and predilections toward not being robbed, and the most elaborate vault door conceived by man. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. For a moment, each man keeps his two dozen questions or more to himself. At last, one speaks up... The Amazing Yen.    In Cantonese.   Of course, no one understands him.    Except Rusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in response) No. Tunneling is out. There are Richter scales monitoring the ground for one hundred yards in every direction. If a groundhog tried to nest there, they'd know about it. Anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another silence. Either the guys are too dumbfounded by that bilingual exchange or too numbed by the task ahead of them to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said something about good news...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, happy someone asked) The Nevada Gaming Commission stipulates: a casino must hold in reserve enough cash to cover every chip at play on its floor. As I mentioned, this vault services each of the three casinos above it. That means: during the week, by law, it must hold anywhere from sixty to seventy million dollars in cash and coin. On a weekend, between eighty and ninety million. On a fight night, like the one two weeks from tonight, the night we're going to rob it, at least a hundred and fifty million. Without breaking a sweat. (gazing about room) Now there are eleven of us. Each with an equal share. You do the math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING AROUND the table ON ten faces, as everyone does precisely that, in their heads, except for Virgil who does it on his fingers. He whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everyone seems suitably impressed by their share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a question. (as Danny turns to him) Say we do get into the cage, and through the security doors there, and down the elevator we can't move, and past the guards with guns, and into the vault we can't open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without being seen by the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off everyone's astonishment) Oh, right. Sorry. I forgot to mention that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say we do all that. We're just supposed to walk outta there with a hundred million dollars in cash on us without getting stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny smiles, his broad, sure-of-himself grin, the one Rusty couldn't deny earlier and these guys won't deny now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saul looks panic-stricken; like that, his ulcer has flared up, and he pops a Rolaid in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   Here's how we'll begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING WITH a cash cart as security guards push it past tourists, past cocktail waitresses, past Linus sitting at a blackjack table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First task: reconnaissance. I want to know everything that's going on in all three casinos. From the rotation of the dealers to the path of every cash cart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two security TECHNICIANS on a smoke break grumble about their sex lives. Across the room, Frank sits innocently doing a crossword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna know everything about every guard, every watcher, anyone with a security pass. I wanna know where they're from, what their nicknames are, how they take their coffee...

dialogues.speaker: BETTER VIEW
dialogues.text: REVEALS: On his crossword, Frank has scribbled a transcript of the Technicians' conversation. As he glances up at an electronic keycard clipped to one Technician's belt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... an identical keycard is swiped through a keypad, its light flashing red to green, admitting a guard into an "Employees Only" doorway. The Malloys, who've shadowed the guard here, note a sentry standing watch by the door as well as a security camera embedded in the ceiling above: No one walks through that portal unchecked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of all, I want you guys to know these casinos. They were built as labyrinths, to keep people in. I want you guys to know the quick routes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their job done, the Malloys start toward the casino's exit... in different directions. They begin to argue: The exit's that way -- no, it's that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two dozen other tourists, Basher crosses the street and when he meets a manhole cover he stops and, extracting a small metal hook from his jacket, removes it from its perch, so casual about the action that no passerby looks twice at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second task: power. On the night of the fight, we're gonna throw the switch on sin city. Basher, it's your show. Basher drops into the hole, pulling the cover over him, as we PULL UP OVER the Bellagio and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of monitors manned by dozens of watchers canvas dozens of casino tables; only NASA's control rooms house more technology. Apart from the fray, another bank of monitors manned by two watchers (let's call them, for no particular reason, FAT and SLIM) oversee a different section of the casino: the cage, its tunnels, the elevator, and the vault it leads to; everything, in fact, which our team saw in the game room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third task: surveillance. Casino security has an eye and ear on everything, so we'll want an eye and ear on them. Livingston...

dialogues.speaker: SCHEMATICS OF BELLAGIO
dialogues.text: A page of the set Danny and Rusty "borrowed" from Kuehn & Associates. Danny and Livingston study it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not the least accessible system I've seen, but it's close. I don't suppose they have a closed-circuit feed I could tap into?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny shakes his head:     no such luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this is definitely a black bag job. Do they employ an in- house technician?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks to Rusty who, behind them, tampers with Livingston's audio-video setup: several portable monitors, a laptop and modem, telephone headset, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.   And one of them is lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANCE MUSIC overwhelms the SOUNDTRACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as we join a lap dance already in progress. A security Technician (one of the two Frank eavesdropped on in the break room) shells out twenty bucks every three minutes for a DANCER to grind her pelvis against his chest... ... and while the Technician grins not-very-soberly and ogles her perfect breasts and paws at her midriff, the Dancer secretly removes the keycard from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back, honey.    Don't move a muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunk and in love) Depends on the muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pouts, flirtingly, as she does for every idiot who drops a line like that, then makes her way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... where Rusty waits for her, and when she slips him the keycard, he slips her a c-note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Charmaine. I'll have it back within the hour. (as he goes) Say hello to your mom for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it yourself. She'll be onstage in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING a bunch of balloons -- all congratulating "Happy Anniversary!" -- as a delivery boy carries them through the casino, and just as he's passing an "Employees Only" door (complete with sentry and embedded ceiling camera)... ... he bumps into a TOURIST, and the balloons drift out of his hand and into the camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch it, bud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the balloons fill the frame of one monitor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 433, we have visual impairment on the east door camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SENTRY (#433) hears this and spots the balloons covering the embedded camera and approaches the delivery boy (who by freak accident happens to be Virgil Malloy)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir: You're going to have to move your balloons. ... but Virgil's too busy picking a fight with the Tourist (surprise, surprise: Turk Malloy) to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you calling 'bud,' pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you calling 'pal,' friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you calling 'friend'... (can't think of another)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... bud... And with the Sentry out of position... ... Livingston (dressed now in a technician's uniform, don't worry about how he got it) goes quickly to the door and swipes the newly-acquired keycard and when it flashes red-to-green, he enters... OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 10/24/00                            48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in. Livingston takes a moment, his brow perspiring (he's in the lions' den now), then checks his palm: drawn there in ballpoint is a diagram of the cage corridors.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR NEXT TO BALLOON-CLOUDED ONE
dialogues.text: Livingston appears and, as nonchalantly as he can, he ambles down a hallway, then another, until he reaches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... an unmarked door next to the entrance to the security center. Livingston swipes his keycard to enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant walk-in closet/switchboard full of wires, plugs, lights, etc. Livingston goes to work:

dialogues.speaker: FLURRY OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: He splices into all sorts of wires and lines and cables. Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Virgil and Turk argue, nose-to-nose, "accidentally" blocking the Sentry from the balloons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear about this new medical discovery they made? It's called a 'sense of direction.' Apparently we're all supposed to have one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah, whatever, balloon boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston's work here is almost done: he clips a small mechanism (known in his industry as a "spider" -- it's small, black, antenna-less and hides in dark places) to a main conduit, then verifies a tiny receiver he holds is picking up the spider's feed. One last click into place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... causes a brief, unnoticed blip on Slim's monitors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and transmits all the views of the cages onto the monitors upstairs. Danny and Rusty witness their appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they paint hallways that color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say taupe is very soothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston steps outside. His job done, he exhales and wipes the sweat from his brow and checks his palm for directions and... Whoops. His sweat just smeared the ballpoint. He's flying blind. He looks left down a corridor, then right, trying to remember which way he came from. No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING WITH Livingston as he tries to find his way out. He takes a left... Whoops again: here comes Fat, dead ahead.    Livingston has no recourse but to march right by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston continues on, and maybe for a second he thinks he's in the clear, especially when he sees the exit looming ahead, but then Fat turns behind him and hails him back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, the Sentry outmaneuvers Virgil and Turk and grabs the balloons himself. Virgil quickly snatches them back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... get your own balloons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston approaches the exit's keypad and swipes his keycard: the light does not flash red-to-green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his tail) Hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livingston looks: he swiped the wrong side of his keycard. He tries again. Red flashes to green. He pulls the door... ... but Fat blocks it.       Livingston peers up, certain had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty simultaneously lean forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dropped this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat holds out Livingston's receiver and drops it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Rusty exhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourth task:    construction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang hauls building materials -- lumber, tools, paint, etc. -- and Yen hauls three times his share, carrying objects on his head/shoulders/arms, a circus act in a hardware store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to build an exact, working replica of the Bellagio vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Linus hauls in materials, Danny takes him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifth task: intelligence. We need those codes, Linus. From the only man who has all three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benedict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn to love his shadow. (back to the team) Sixth task: transport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (young and eager) Wait, wait, wait. All I get to do is watch him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now. You gotta walk before you crawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Linus, correcting Danny) Reverse that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toward the Malloys) Sixth task: transport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside a window: Turk and Virgil jump up and down on opposite bumpers of a van, testing its durability. Inside, Frank negotiates with BILLY TIM, a Cal- Worthingtonesque redneck car dealer, who half-pays attention to him, half-frets over the Malloys outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry: eighteen-five each is the best offer I can make you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing a bit of a dandy) Oh, I understand perfectly. They are beautiful vans. Well, I thank you for your time, Mister...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denham.   Billy Tim Denham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Denham, like a jean. (they shake) You know: you have lovely hands -- do you moisturize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OCEAN'S 11 - Rev. 1/8/01

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank's not letting go of the man's hand, the object now is to force Billy Tim into lowering his price just to get Frank out of his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear by it. I try all sorts of lotions. I went through a fragrance-free period last year, but now I'm liking this new brand fortified with rose hip. My sister, you know, she uses the aloe vera with the sun screen built in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just can't get his hand back) Uh-huh. You said you'd be willing to pay in cash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
